channel.title: Plutarch Speaks
channel.description: Daily deep-cut business case studies narrated by Plutarch, your learned Greek tutor-slave. Drawing from Harvard Business Review and historical corporate documentation, each episode illuminates timeless lessons from the annals of commerce.
channel.itunes:author: Plutarch
channel.itunes:summary: Daily deep-cut business case studies narrated by Plutarch. Timeless lessons from HBR and corporate history.

item.title: V. The Osborne Effect
item.description: Silicon Valley, 1981. Adam Osborne built a $100 million computer company in eighteen months. Then, at a press conference, he announced his next-generation products — and destroyed his own sales overnight. The "Osborne Effect" became a permanent term for pre-announcement suicide. A meditation on timing, confidence, and the fatal gap between vision and delivery.
item.itunes:summary: How a visionary entrepreneur killed his own company by announcing products too early. The birth of "The Osborne Effect" — a mistake that recurs in tech to this day.

item.title: IV. The Ratners Gaffe
item.description: London, 1991. Gerald Ratner had built the world's largest jewelry chain. Then, at the Royal Albert Hall before six thousand executives, he called his products "total crap." Five hundred million pounds evaporated. His name became a verb for self-destruction. A meditation on audience, aspiration, and the catastrophic weight of careless words.
item.itunes:summary: How one joke at a business conference destroyed half a billion pounds. The story of Gerald Ratner and the sacred compact of aspiration.

item.title: III. The Death of Schlitz
item.description: Milwaukee, 1970. Schlitz was America's best-selling beer. Within a decade, it would be worthless — destroyed not by competitors but by its own executives' cost-cutting obsession. The tale of how "The Beer That Made Milwaukee Famous" became a cautionary tale about brand destruction.
item.itunes:summary: How relentless cost-cutting destroyed America's #1 beer brand. A lesson on brand promises, the seduction of optimization, and the things spreadsheets cannot measure.

item.title: II. The South Sea Bubble
item.description: London, 1720. A single share rises from one hundred to one thousand pounds, then crashes to thirty-seven. Isaac Newton loses his fortune. A nation learns that markets can lie. The story of history's first great financial crash, and the eternal lesson it failed to teach.
item.itunes:summary: London, 1720. History's first great financial crash. Isaac Newton loses his fortune. A lesson in the eternal madness of markets.

item.title: I. The Tylenol Crisis of 1982
item.description: Seven deaths from cyanide-laced capsules. Johnson & Johnson's response—the recall of thirty-one million bottles at ruinous cost—became the gold standard for crisis management. A meditation on stakeholder prioritization and the peculiar economics of trust.
item.itunes:summary: Seven deaths from cyanide-laced capsules. J&J's radical transparency response became the gold standard for crisis management.

item.title: 0. The Arthashastra
item.description: India, circa 320 BCE. The ascetic Brahmin Chanakya presents to the young Emperor Chandragupta Maurya a manuscript that would shape governance for two millennia: the Arthashastra, the world's first comprehensive treatise on economics, statecraft, and political philosophy. An introduction to our series, and a meditation on the deep roots of the science of wealth.
item.itunes:summary: The world's first economics treatise, presented in the court of Chandragupta Maurya. An introduction to our series.
